thread.title: Scientists recreate face of a man murdered 1400 years ago
thread.title_full: Scientists recreate face of a man murdered 1400 years ago

title: Scientists recreate face of a man murdered 1400 years ago
text:
Scientists recreate face of a man murdered 1400 years ago Last updated 13:42, February 18 2017 UNIVERSITY OF DUNDEE 
Forensic anthropologist Dame Sue Black described the man's appearance as "striking". 
Researchers have recreated the face of a man who was murdered in the Scottish highlands 1400 years ago. 
The man's skeleton was discovered in a cave, lying in an unusual cross-legged position, with large stones holding down his legs and arms. Analysis revealed he met a brutal end, Metro reported. 
University of Dundee anthropologist Professor Dame Sue Black detailed his terrible injuries. 
The man's skeleton was found in a cross-legged position, with large stones holding down his legs and arms 
"As you can see from the facial reconstruction, he was a striking young man but he met a very brutal end, suffering a minimum of five severe injuries to his head. 
"The fourth impact was intended to end his life as probably the same weapon was driven through his skull from one side and out the other as he lay on the ground," she said. 
The young man suffered terrible injuries more than 1000 years ago. UNIVERSITY OF DUNDEE 
The man's skeleton was found by archaeologists excavating the hideaway in the Black Isle. 
The bones were sent to University of Dundee's Centre for Anatomy and Human Identification (CAHID) for analysis. Experts painstakingly reconstructed the man's face from his battered skull. 
Radiocarbon dating indicated he died some time between 430 and 630 AD.
